title: Chick Egg Cup
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A rather whimsical egg cup shaped like a chick. I looked at the existing egg cup designs on Thingiverse and rather liked http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7834 by bpijls. So I set out to design something similar for chicken eggs. This model holds eggs that are 42-46mm diameter. To fit larger eggs, you can either scale the .stl model or edit the parts directly in Tinkercad https://tinkercad.com/things/hvw1rSKFOVa

The overhang at the base of the cup can be difficult to print. I succeeded to print with:
â€¢ 0.35 layer height
â€¢ 4 perimeter shells
â€¢ 35% infill using a concentric pattern
â€¢ switching the cooling fan on only after the first 20 layers
â€¢ no supports (but you might need them) Oh, and be very gentle removing the cup from the build platform, many chick feet have been harmed in the making of this thing.

title: Halloween Unicorn Mask (remixed for 5mm LED)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Printing time: ~8.5h (with the last 30mins for the horn)
Filament: ~25m (~35m with support)

I made these for some collegues, and they all wanted to keep the printing pattern and no sanding. So I painted it with acryl purple and black on the inside. Although the inside turned out as a bad idea xD

The mask is printed with the horn pointing upwards, so you can change filament to transparent.. (read notes below)

This version has a 5mm LED mount, with an extra cable hole and a CR2032 battery mount.
(essentially 3 holes, 6mm for the led, 20mm for the battery with a 2mm cable canal)

The LEDs are RGB color changing 2pin 3.3v versions, with a chip that does the mood light.
The batteries only have 3v but it's enough for a cool effect.

Check out the video of a prototype: https://twitter.com/cccfr/status/933030858650419200

description.text:
A pair of 200x200 shapes to test large area Z-cal, and more interestingly warping of the bed. Printed with as little squishing as you can still get adhesion, any low or high points will show as rough/smooth first layer once the print is cooled and removed.

With a MK42 bed on a I3 Mk2, I was seeing poor adhesion at the rear left of the cal2 test - the perimeter of hte bed was OK, but the middle seems slightly dished. To compensate, I set 'bed level correction' -ve at the back, and +ve at the front.

title: Fish-On Compatible Fishing Rod Holder Mount for 1.5in x .25in Gunnel Rails on Aluminum Drift Boats
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Print Model upside down and it will print with out supports.

This is a fishing rod holder mount that I made for my 1986 Alumaweld drift boat, it works with Fish-on rod holders.

This allows you to mount to the gunnel rail with out drilling holes in your boat. It works great we have been using them for a while now. Once the slot is dropped over the gunnel rail the to bolts both pinch the rail but also pin it in place so that it can not fall off or slide away. This makes it real easy to relocate your rod holders in a hurry with out drilling new holes.

This might work on Willies, Koffler, newer or older Alumaweld and other aluminum drift boats with similar size gunnel rails. I plan on making some that fit a couple different boats so if you have one that you can send me rail dimensions for id be happy to adjust the design. This one is for use n a 1.5in x .25in (1-1/2X1/4in) or 7mm x 50mm Gunnel Rail.

These might also work with scotty style rod holders i have yet to confirm but it should be close.

This uses an M6x30mm bolts like these:
http://amzn.to/2zfTGea

With an M6 nylock nut like these:
http://amzn.to/2A6UmE7 or these http://amzn.to/2zgxvVn
or you could use a knob like this on the back for quick adjustment http://amzn.to/2BgeQdz

You can also use a 1/4in-20x1.25 bolt and matching nut or knob.

title: Gregs wade extruder mount for Folgertech Prusa i3 2020 X-Axis Upgrade Openbuilds V-Slot Rail System with 20mm inductive sensor

description.text:
This bracket allows use of a gregs wade style extruder, a lj18a3-8-z/bx 18mm inductive sensor and the Folgertech Prusa i3 2020 X-Axis Upgrade (Openbuilds V-Slot Rail System) found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1285301

I found I had much better luck with inductive bed leveling using the lj18a3-8-z/bx sensor but it seems it's not used very often by others so there are not a lot of mounting options available.

Looking closely at the pictures you'll see I had to grind out some plastic with a dremel to be able to turn the set screws for the inductive sensor. I haven't fixed this in the model yet.

I have since moved on to using a e3d titan aero extruder and no longer use this bracket, but I continue using the sensor, it works really well.

author: mccartyb03

remixed_from.author: Simhopp
remixed_from.title: USB Power Bank for Ryobi 18v One+ battery

description.text:
This is a battery pack to use two Ryobi One+ batteries with a tool (https://youtu.be/KomE9KIKsI4). It has mounting points for two batteries (any kind of Ryobi One+ battery is supported) and a switch to select which battery is powering the tool. This does not link the batteries in series and does not increase voltage to the tool. (You could wire it differently and run your tools at higher voltage but you wouldn't do that, would you?) (Don't. But if you do, record it and put it on YouTube!) *Note: this may not work with all tools -- think about the direction of the battery socket and how much space there is around it for the tool you want to use. (For example, this would not work with my Ryobi circular saw since one of the batteries would extend below the saw shoe.)

This design borrows heavily from flyingaz's Milwaukee to Ryobi Battery Adapter design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1677812) and simhopp's USB Power Bank for Ryobi 18v One+ Battery (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1897607/). I would not have been able to put this together without using their designs.

I used PLA to print this. Be careful tightening the screws, the hole loops on the bottom are not very strong and easily break if overtightened. I was planning on using four screws to hold the two lower halves together but later realized that I didn't need the top two screws since the switch box has four mounting screws joining the two halves.

Non-plastic pieces used:
(1) DPDT switch (I used a Gardner Bender GSW-16 toggle switch)
(6) pieces of 14-gauge solid wire
(4) #8 3/4" screws (use 5 #8 1" or 1-1/4" screws if using SwitchBox_v4 & TopStem_v2)
(4) #6 1/2" screws
(2) #6 1" screws
(2) 3/8" x 5/8" springs
(2) 1/2" tube strap pipe hangers
(2) small screws & nuts (or rivets)
(6) loop terminals for 14ga wire

Plastic Pieces:
(2) Battery shells
(1) Switch box
(1) Top stem
(2) Buttons
(4) Wire posts

Print & assembly instructions:

  1. Print two 'battery shells'. I used 25% infill, .2mm layer height, high speed, normal shells. Approximately 4.5 hours and 17.8 meters of filament each.
  2. Cut away support material from battery shells using utility knife or Dremel tool
  3. Print one 'switch box'. I used 20% infill, .2mm layer height, high speed, normal shells. Approximately 1.75 hours and 8.3 meters of filament.
  4. Print one 'top stem'. I used 25% infill, .2mm layer height, high speed, normal shells. Approximately 4 hours and 17.1 meters of filament.
  5. Print one set of 'wire posts'. I printed these with 90% infill, .2mm layer height, medium speed, normal shells. Approximately 1.5 hours and 3.2 meters of filament.
  6. Print two 'buttons'. I printed these with 90% infill, .4mm layer height, high speed, normal shells. Approximately 20 minutes, 1.9 meters of filament.
  7. Attach the two battery shells using two or four #6 1" screws. Be careful not to overtighten them.
  8. Drill holes for wires to pass through from switch box into the space between the battery shells. I would like to add a passage for wires but did not get to it so far.
  9. Run four wires from switch box into the battery shells, two for each battery. Make sure you can identify which wire is which, I used different colors for each wire.
  10. Cut away excess material from wire posts (I printed them together because they fell over when I tried to print them individually).
  11. Insert wires into wire posts, push them into battery shells and push excess wire into the space between battery shells. (See simhopp's USB adapter post for a photo of how the wires fit into the wire posts.)
  12. Attach switch box to top of the battery shells using four #6 1/2" screws.
  13. Flatten and bend 1/2" strips of metal for battery contacts on the top stem. I soldered them to two short wires that connect to the switch, this could also be done with loop terminals. After attaching these two wires, drill holes in the top stem and fasten the metal contacts to the top stem using rivets or short screws.
  14. Insert buttons into the top stem with 3/8"x5/8" springs.
  15. Connect all six wires to your switch, I used loop terminals to do this. Make sure you can identify which wires are positive/negative and which connect to each battery before you do this. I had my wires like this: Load A1 (blue wire), Line A (black), Load A2 (brown), Load B1 (red), Line B (white), Load B2 (green). The switch box was a tight fit for my switch, I wished I had made it larger to allow more room for wires and terminals (but it does all fit).
  16. Push switch into place and attach top stem to switch box using four #8 3/4" screws.

Total estimated print time: 17 hours
Total estimated filament used: ~66 meters

Update: after about a day I'm seeing some delamination in the middle front wall of the switch box (opposite where the switch toggle is). I hope making the walls thicker (and making the switch box larger overall) and using longer screws from the top stem into the switch box may help. Printing with higher infill might also help.

Update 2: I've added a new version of the switch box and top stem to make it stronger. I reassembled it today and so far it's holding up better. The updated version is 'SwitchBox_v4' and 'TopStem_v2'. (You can use SwitchBox_v4 with TopStem_v1 -- it just won't have the 5th screw hole on the front.) With the updated pieces, you can use #8 3/4", 1" or 1-1/4" screws.

title: Frog Pad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My daughter made a frog from rocks for Father's Day one year. It doesn't sit flat very well and falls over easily. Because she signed the bottom, I didn't want to cover it up with something to make it sit flat. I decided this was a good excuse to buy a 3D scanner. I scanned the bottom of the frog and turned it into a solid to use as a tool to split another object. I designed a Lilly pad leaf and then cut out the impression of the bottom of the frog so it would sit flat on my desk.

I thought the Lilly pad might be useful to someone.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The bottom of the leaf isn't flat. I used the slicer to drop it down by 0.3 mm to get a flatter surface and better adhesion to the print bed. Smaller layer heights will provide better leaf detail since the changes are shallow.

I used a Ciclop 3D scanner to scan the bottom of the frog and then cleaned the point clouds in Meshlab, generated the mesh and exported as an STL file (that was a big learning curve.). I then imported the mesh into Fusion 360 cleaned it a little more and converted it to a solid. Then I designed the leaf using the sculpting feature of Fusion 360 and a reference image from the internet. The leaf is what is provided in this thing. I removed the frog bottom from the leaf and printed it out using two colors. It turned out better than I hoped, especially after struggling with the point clouds in Meshlab.

title: Alquerque & Catch the Hare Board Games
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Alquerque is played with 12 black pieces and 12 white pieces.
The player playing black pieces places them on the 10 points of the nearest 2 rows plus the 2 rightmost points on the middle row as the player looks at it. The other player sets the white pieces up in exactly the same way. This leaves only the middle point without a piece upon it. The objective of the game is to take all of the opponent's pieces or to produce a position such that the opponent is unable to move.
You may use the pawn in two colors or have a Roger Moore vs Pierce Brosnan set.

description.text: This is a stretched X FT Gremlin racing frame. Designed for max speed, the stretched X design allows the back props to get clean air at a forward flying angle. This is the second puzzle I designed. This puzzle is slightly larger than the first Mini Puzzle I designed, measuring about 30 mm x 40 mm. Each piece started as a full-sized block shape, in 5 mm-increments. I then measured 0.150 mm inside of each side to make a border that is 0.150 mm thick around every piece. I then removed that small area outside the measurements, making the parts of the pieces that stick out slightly thinner, and the pieces that are inward, wider. I found that 0.150 mm makes the pieces fit together wonderfully. No pressure or any force needed, but no big spaces either. Then I made each piece 5 mm tall. It's a pretty basic puzzle, with only 7 pieces; 3 more pieces than my first puzzle. I hope you enjoy this puzzle if you make one, And would love to see it if you did!

title: Teal Sport Top Cover - Dimpled (golf ball style)

description.text: A modification of the stock top cover to add golf ball style dimples. Currently sized the same as a golf ball (.157" diameter, 0.01" depth). Theoretically should change how the drone behaves in flight, though some experimentation would obviously be needed, and the different flight model (propellers vs. lift generating flight surfaces) might make this modification completely irrelevant; still worth testing.

comments.text: If you are looking to go fast, this might not work great as air will flow into the dimples, hit the back of them, and slow the drone. It might even tip over if you go super fast, though that is very unlikely. If you are going to use this to get some excellent footage at a golf game or tournament, it would be a great aesthetic!
comments.author: TuckyIA

comments.text:
Im using golfball dimples on my desighn too and yes maybe there is no point in that. But its all experimental.
The reason for them is to generate tiny air turbulances in there pit to let the main airstream flow over them and let the air generate a smaller tail at the end of the object.
comments.author: TuckyIA

comments.text: As I said in the description, and in reply to MazeMieter - I'm not sure if this will work or not.  Though I'm not sure about that specific failure mode (the dimples are very shallow, so I don't believe they'd produce that much extra resistance), it definitely is something I'll keep in mind if I do get a chance to test the original vs. my modified design.
comments.author: TuckyIA

comments.text: Ahhh..the last entry is again a dejavu golfball design. Ever wondered why there are no cars or trucks using this pattern? Because it's only useful on a spinning golf ball.
comments.author: MazeMieter

comments.text: Hey man, I even put in the description the idea might be fundamentally flawed - I just think it'd be fun to test.  I have some other ideas as well (embossed or debossed vanes parallel to the average direction of travel of the drone, dimples/vanes/some other feature on the top plate near the props to mitigate prop wash, again if that's even a concern - I haven't used a Teal drone, nor any N-copter in a while), but this is the one I could get together in half an hour, as I only saw this contest yesterday.

title: Laser Cut Lake Tahoe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this as an engineering project at school. I worked on this project with my group for about a month. I used Fusion 360 and mainly the spline tool to trace out an outline of each layer in Lake Tahoe. The final product came out very nicely and we made two different models. One model using wood and the other with cardboard. We used paint to give the lake some color and a spray of clear coat to make it shine. We also used wood stain on the top layer to create contrast between the water and land.

The neat thing with making this lake is that you can customize it:

  • You can cut as many or little layers as your want
  • You can cut it out of different materials
  • You can make it as big or as small as you like
  • You can add different land/water features (Nevada/Cali border, forests, lakes, streets, water depth)

title: BattleCon Kit Boxes v1.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
*(V1.0) Cleaned up project, updated description, added source file.

A set of boxes meant to hold a full kit for characters from the BattleCon game series. These have been sized to fit the following from any one character:

  • A characters full kit (standup + cards + tokens + counters, etc.)
  • Striker card
  • EX/Almighty character versions
  • Alternate costumes

*(The source file is included).

I used Endrbyt's kit as the template for this, but for smaller kits (such as Eligors), you should be able to store a set of bases as well. This considers sleeved cards so non-sleeved cards should have a bit of extra space.

  • This is currently true for every character except for Thessala who's evolution board is the size of a stage card and does not fit. (Thanks to Andarel for the info).

The original box has 1.5mm walls (to reduce printing time), but if you find the box too frail, I added a 2.5 mm version as well.

Do let me know of any suggestions and be sure to tag this if you use it. Have fun.

description.text: Martial arts weapon designed to attack pressure points, occasionally used by law enforcement to subdue suspects by non-lethal force.

I printed my kubaton in a horizontal orientation with raft and supports. I got some crappy printing on the overhang of the point, Makerware didn't think it needed supports for that part, apparently.  
I'd recommend printing at a minimum of 50% infill, higher if you have the plastic and the patience. It's going to have a fair amount of stress applied to it, and the first time you have to use it in self-defense would be a very bad time for it to break.  
The hexagonal bore through most of the grip was added to allow for the addition of lead bird shot (or similar) to increase the mass of the kubaton. If this was a bad idea as far as structural strength, I'm open to suggestions for fixes.  
And I feel obligated to say... Please be careful with this. The tip of the kubaton is still fairly sharp (something I may fix in a later version) and could cause real damage if used improperly.  
Anyways, enjoy, and most importantly, be safe.

author: bjwilliams241

title: Motorola Droid Bionic Docking Station // Tripod

description.text:
Often I want my phone to remain upright. Sometimes because I'm watching something on it, sometimes because I'm taking a photo.
Here's a docking station I made today that will elevate it about 40mm off the ground/table (so you can have it be plugged in simultaneously).

Print just the dock or the dock + 2 legs. I used hot glue to attach them, because I'm silly like that (and also bc hot glue makes a great rubber-esque grip surface for the bottom of the feet).
Please let me know some better connection protocols for the feet -> stand (right now there's a simple insert peg).
NOTE: This is for the Motorola Droid Bionic with extended battery.

title: Case for 5" LCD panel DIY tv/monitor

description.text:
Given a 5" lcd panel and driver board, figured I'd make a little case; its not super polished but is utilitarian ... does the job. Should fit many or most 5" LCD panels, such as the ones you can get from Adafruit.

Example kit you can stuff in here:
https://www.adafruit.com/product/1678

Obviously, the lcd panel is up front; the lcd frame has a bevel on the inside to help support the LCD and keep the viewing area in the right place. There is a cutout on the side for your driver boards input ports (such as HDMI, VGA, composite, power etc.) I didn't make it specific port cutouts as I didnt' want to invest that much time (honesty counts :), and there are affair variety of driver boards available (USB power, DC Barrel jack power; and a slew of possible input signals...); lastly, there is a cutout on top (again, lazily done) for a common set of button strips that I've seen .. some may fit, others you might need to x-acto or hacksaw a bit of space depending where the ribbon cable is and so forth.

description.text: Spool Holder

print_settings.Resolution:: Prints at low/med/high however you get the best results on the narrow groves at med / high resolution.
print_settings.Notes:: Notes:  if you see loosely connected filament on the bottom of the shell it means your bottom layer is not "squishing" down into the print-bed enough.  In Simplify3D I adjusted the z-offset under layers to -0.04 to move it closer to the bed for the bottom shell.

description.text:
I created a case for my X8R receiver since my receiver is the one with PCB antenna's. This is a tight fit on the PCB antenna covers if you have solder blobs connecting them as one of mine had, but you can still slide them into the PCB protectors without resoldering since I made them long enough.

I printed mine out of ABS and made sure weak spots were re-enforced. The design leaves the smart port freely accessible.

Update: I uploaded a V2 version that has deeper grooves for the wires and narrower PCB antenna protectors at the end to help "clip" in the antenna's. The locking tab is also a tiny bit taller to help lock in the X8R.

Printer:

Tevo Little Monster

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Prints at low/med/high however you get the best results on the narrow groves at med / high resolution.

Infill:

30% to 40%

Notes:

I did not use rafts as with the heated bed at 110C and Using Wolf Bite ABS formula the case remains firmly attached until the bed cools. I used 230C extruder temps for the ABS.

Notes: if you see loosely connected filament on the bottom of the shell it means your bottom layer is not "squishing" down into the print-bed enough. In Simplify3D I adjusted the z-offset under layers to -0.04 to move it closer to the bed for the bottom shell.

Designed in sketchup 2017

description.text:
This model was created in Autodesk Fusion 360 using the sweep tool. It is a design for 3d printed fabric. The model is very flexible and can easily be printed at a larger scale. You can simply open multiple versions of the STL file in the slicer and put them together to create a larger piece of fabric. Also included is a model of an individual loop that can be used to create different shapes of fabric by putting the models together in the slicer.

Dimensions: Each loop is about 13mm x 13mm x 11mm, but can be easily scaled. The included model of a small, assembled piece of fabric is about 45mm x 45mm x 11mm.

Note: These models can be combined in the slicer to produce the desired size of fabric.

For tutorials and information about CAD and 3d printing, you can visit my website at: https://www.constrain3d.wordpress.com

author: VA3TNE

description.text:
I decided to create a series of mounts. There's already some great horses on thingiverse, but I wanted to give a wide selection of mount types.

We have:

  • Horse
  • Unicorn
  • Tiger
  • Lion
  • Bear
  • Dire Wolf
  • Dire Boar
  • Rhino

The mount platform is sized to hold mins with the 25mm bases that are common in pathfinder and D&D prepaint minis. If you want to have it hold something a little larger or square, just resize on the y axis to like 110% or a little more. All mounts have been sliced in half, and on fdm printers should be printed from the cut files. I did it in .1 layer height with supports.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

As most of you know, Gearbest provided me with their Tronxy X5s printer. This full set was printed on the printer, and I'm very happy with how they came out. Overall, the Tronxy X5s is now printing better then my Prusa i3 in pretty much every way. I still use both, but I'm doing prints on this printer first in almost every case because they come out with less need for cleanup then the ones on my prusa.

Changelog
  • 1/30/2018 - Fixed some files for manifold issues: Bear, Dire Tiger, Dire Wolf, Lion, Rhino

title: Shampoo bottle Holder - to - Get every last drop OUT !

description.text:
Shampoo bottles with rounded tops may look nice, but waste the last 20% to 30% - a ploy of cynical Manufacturers to sell more Shampoo - so FU2 manufacturers.

My nifty holder holds it upside down, and allows every last drop to be used - the bottle that was considered empty & unusable has been squirting out Shampoo for several weeks now & still going strong.

As Aldi & Coles/Woolworths have slightly different sizes I've provided holders for both - enjoy !

author: geoff_cohen

print_settings.Notes:: I split this model so you can minimize support scarring.  The Empire is coming.  We've picked up something outside the base in zone twelve, moving east.

description.text:
This is the robot from the icy snowy planet in the Fifth movie and not screen accurate. Model is finished and print verified. This model is best printed at 100% scale on FDM. SLA/SLS - go as small as you'd like. I find on FDM, 120% to 130% scale works really well and all the details show super nicely.

Dec 27, 2017 Update - Added a new bottom which changes the orientation fo the legs and some bottom hardware. See instructions below. Enjoy.

Nov 27, 2017 - Added a new head with a rounded top and better antenna nubs. Also added a new body top and a thinner lower body. I removed all the split heads because the split along the seam on the model - prints well but makes it harder to assemble. I would suggest splitting it vertically between some of the eyes and then laying that edge to the build plate.

Printing the Model:

  • Print 3 sets of the LongLeg 1,2 &3
  • Print 2 sets of the ShortLeg 1 & 2
  • Print 5 of the claws of any mix and match between the 3 styles
  • Print one head of your choice.
  • Print one body top and one body bottom
  • Print display post with higher infill
  • Print the base - Hoth

Assembly:

  • Glue the body top to body bottom. You can align it to the full body or anyway you like.
  • Glue the head parts together.
  • For the legs, glue the upper and lower and the claw. Position them the way you like and then glue to the bottom body
  • Use the peg to hold the head to the body. This allows the head to spin on the body. You know for that critical missed shot against a big hairy monkey and that bag of mostly salty water named Nan.
  • Glue the display post to the display stand
  • For the long range comm antennas, I did not include them. You should take a piece of filament and heat it up and stretch it out. Cut 2 equal length pieces and glue on the antenna nubs. There's no point in trying to print these since it can't be done.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

10% or less

Notes:

I split this model so you can minimize support scarring. The Empire is coming. We've picked up something outside the base in zone twelve, moving east.

comments.text:
Hi, I'm new to 3D printing.
Printing using a Creality CR10S with 1.76mm PLA.
What does FDM and SLA/SLS mean?
comments.author: Geoff_RageQuit

comments.text: Your CR10S is a FDM (filament deposition model) type printer.  SLA - Stereo Lithography (using laser or light projection).  SLS - is laser sintering.  Both SLA and SLS will have much higher resolution than FDM.  Enjoy your new hobby.  Lots of CR10 users out there.

title: Printrbot Metal Plus Dual Extruder Blower Fans

description.text:
Improve print quality on your Dual Extruder Printrbot Metal Plus by replacing the factory fans and shroud with dual blower fans. This provides much higher air flow for significantly improved print cooling.

Printrbot has a bracket and shroud for a 50mm blower fan for the single extruder Metal Plus, but these are not compatible with the dual extruder version of the printer.

In this upgrade, the left blower mounts with the intake facing up, and the right blower is flipped 180° so that the intake is facing towards the bed.

description.text:
This is a magazine coupler for Gen 3 PMAGs to couple 2 10 round magazines together, intended for those living in stupid states. This does not extend the capacity of the individual magazines.

This coupler is under a lot of spring tension so print this with thick walls and lots of infill. So far 1.6mm/80% has held together without it exploding and shooting springs across the room. I am not responsible if this fails at any point in any way.

To decouple the magazines insert a small screwdriver or similar device into the slot in the back and rotate it to push up the individual magazine insert buttons, carefully sliding out that magazine. Remember, spring tension.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select 3D V2

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

80%

Notes:

This is still a work in progress. If printed in ABS it seems to fit OK. If printed in PLA minor sanding was required in the coupler channels that slide over the bottom of the magazine due variations in material expansion characteristics. Sand the coupler, not the magazine.

Got myself one of those Prusa -i3 Chinese made printers. (Just starting with 3D printing stuff)

Not fancy but gets the job done. - Better safe than sorry.
Cover simply screws into the side of power supply. Rear left open for cable entry and to allow air-flow for cooling fan.

This device is used for improving the quality of photospheres taken from Android devices. It has been designed to rotate in two directions exactly around the the lens of my Nexus 5X with its case on, so unless you have the exact same phone and case it may not work as well for you as it does for me, but it should still be a significant improvement over taking the pictures freehand. It can be mounted to a GoPro mount, or be used free standing, although you'll probably want to use some blu-tack on the feet to stop it from sliding.
The dimensions of the phone holder are 13.5mm x 81.0mm. It has an open top, so the height of your phone doesn't matter, so long as your camera lens is at least 90mm above the base, otherwise it will be blocked.

description.text:
I want to make a life sized JoelBot to present to Joel at MRRF next year, similar to the life-sized Rick from Rick and Morty. By my calculations, Joel is approximately 1854mm tall.

I plan on printing all the parts with the PLA I have and sand and painting it, unless proto-pasta or matterhackers wants to send me 5kg of blue filament (high-five blue would be awesome). If you would like to contribute filament or printer time to this cause (it will be shipped to MRRF 2018) please PM me or comment.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

This is by far the biggest print I'll ever do so filament supply is an issue.

I broke this down so that all the parts will fit within the build volume of the Prusa i3 Mk2. The biggest piece is less than 240mm x 200mm x 150mm. There are 39 pieces total, I labeled them by the anatomical names so it's easier to follow.

I have not sliced and estimated filament cost or time yet, I'm imagining several hundred hours and at least 5 spools will be needed. I will probably keep these parts at 3 perimeters and 5% infill to keep it light.

I would recommend drilling a hole through each piece and using a dowel rod all the way through, especially if standing him up on a platform, by itself it will probably break or need to be propped up because of the weight distribution, glue, and layer weaknesses.

comments.author: lrlinnell

comments.text: In TinkerCAD to separate pieces from a part you've got to do a lot of copy and pasting and eliminating or spearting the pieces how you want them.  For example.  If you pull up this stl in tinkercAd you want to first copy the whole piece and then work on the copy by elimination or deleting the parts that you  want to separate and then copying the editing piece, opening a new design and pasting it in there, save it then download it. Now go back to the original and eliminate the pieces that you copied into the new design and you've now split the file in two.  Hope that helps!

title: Solar Power Supply for Weatherstation or any device needing 3.3v

description.text:
I have a weather station that runs on 2 AA batteries which lasts for about 4 weeks and I thought it would be a good idea if I could make a solar power supply.

Note this same design could be used to power almost any device that needs 3.2 volts,for instance an Arduino based weather sensor you make yourself.

You can replace the Buck converter I used to generate almost any voltage required.

I used the 500mAh battery from a quad copter I already had, but any 3.7 volt lithium cell can be used, provided you change the design to allow it to fit.

If anyone wants a copy of the CAD files contact me, I used Fusion 360.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

The lid will need to be rotated by 180 degrees before printing

Make sure the groove for the silicon bead is clear of any plastic from the print, before inserting the bead.

The photo of the lid shows how the white bead should be fitted, note don't fit it around the edge on the corners!

Put the end of the bead at the short edge to ensure there is less chance for water to penetrate the enclosure.

I didn't use any glue to hold the bead in place as it wasn't required.

You can always clean up the print using sand paper and a coat of paint if you want to.

After some research I found a control board that can take the power from the solar cell and control the charging of the lithium cell. The board also uses the energy in the panel when the sun shines or the battery to output 3.6 volts.

My weather station only needs between 3-3.5v.
Luckily there are plenty of cheap controller boards available.
I have also used Silicone rubber cord to act as the water seal.

After buying the electronics I put them together to make sure it all worked before designing the case. I have used a number of commercially available cases before and tried to use some of the design features to ensure the electronics are kept dry.

The fixing screws are therefore outside of the water proof area inside the box. An important feature is the silicon cord which acts as the water seal between the case and the lid.

I used a hot glue gun to fix the solar cell to the lid but you could use silicon sealer just as easily.

The thermistor is used to monitor the battery temperature and prevent charging below -10C and above 70C as this could damage the battery

Dosetti eli lääkeannostelija suomenkielisillä viikonpäivillä. Annostelijaan mahtuu 14 päivän lääkkeet, ja lisäksi on yksi ylimääräinen osasto esimerkiksi päänsärkytableteille. Kotelo on tukeva ja pienikokoinen, ja se soveltuu hyvin myös matkakäyttöön.

title: Cigarette box for hand rolled cigarettes

description.text:
Self-rolled cigarettes are hard to store in conventional cigarette cases as the length of a standard rolling paper is only 70mms and when hand rolled cigarettes move around in the case, they tend to lose the tobacco filling in the tip.

My idea was to create a practical yet elegant case which stores up to 4 hand-rolled cigarettes. As hinges and latches seem to be a common source for failed prints and require a lot of tedioius post-processing work, I opted to add 4 powerfull magnets (5x5x3mm) to keep the lids together.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

45%

Notes:

Best printed in high resolution of 0.1-0.2 mm layer height. After breaking off the supports carefully and sanding the interior of the lids, glue in the magnets flush to the surface. Make sure to watch the polarity of the magnets before gluing them in as you want them to attract each other.

In the pictures shown, I did not sand the the outside of the case as it seemed quite ok for my standards.

Brim: better not, but if unavoidable consider not using a brim on the inside as it difficult to remove in the small gaps for the magnets.

Push magnet(s) through hole as illustrated in wireframe image.

I recently had a need to look under the floorboards to check on some pipework and the only easy access was a knothole less than 20mm diameter. A cheap borescope (£7.00 on eBay) gave a good picture but was difficult to manouvre to see what I was looking for. An unwound wire coat-hanger and electrical tape prove no solution so I quickly printed up a borescope steering mechanism based on what little information I could find on medical endoscopes.
I have put a video on YouTube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QbhHUqesBow showing the steering mechanism doing its thing with an inset picture showing the view from the borescope camera. I have avoided puting up a video showing what I found under the floor as it would distress anybody even slightly arachnophobic. I have put together a fairly comprehensive description of how to make this in a PDF file in the Thing Files

Fractal-based volumetric object that resembles a neuron.
RAW data 400x400x400 8-bit zipped
PNG codec AVI 400x400x400
PLY isosurface mesh 494K polygons
STL isosurface mesh 494K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects. Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here: 40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371 Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here: http://www.engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

title: Lithophane Display Case - Portrait Mode
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For Christmas this year, I made my sister a lithophane of our late father and her children. Needing a nice display case for it, I designed this one. It is designed to take standard 4x6" photos-turned-lithophanes with a depth of 3mm and sized 100x146mm in the portrait (up and down) orientation.

If there is enough interest, I may remix this into a complimentary landscape mode display.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print the top piece upside down and it will print without supports. For the bottom piece, you will need supports enabled for everywhere to support the LED clip.

As for resolution, I printed the bottom piece and the legs at 0.2mm. The top piece was printed at 0.3mm since there wasn't any real detail there.

For the back light, I used this - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01H36HLAK - At 10 pieces for $7 (at the time of my purchase), you cannot go wrong. You will need to solder the power supply wires to the chip, since there was not enough room to model in a USB connector. With the LEDs facing up and the USB pads towards you, positive is on the right and negative is on the left. The two middle pads are unused.

Fresh off the printer, the light is brighter at the bottom and darker at the top - which I expected. To counteract this, I lined the inside of the "top" piece with aluminum foil tape - the type used for A/C duct work. I placed one strip across the top and two strips side by side up and down the rear panel. This was enough to reflect the light and even out any dim areas. You might want to place a strip on each of the side panels too, just for better coverage.

For the pins that hold the legs on, you can use 3mm filament if you have any laying around. If not, I have included pegs that you can print. The two shorter pins go in the two front holes. The rest are all the same, longer, length.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
V1.7

Untested 85mm Brushed Micro Drone WIP:

My concept is to soft mount the motors and flight controller, to this quadcopter frame, with rubber bands instead of screws.

The motor mounts are for 7mm x 20mm motors.

New in this version. 4 x 30mm nylon spacers. Thinking to use small zip ties for the landing gear and extra crash protection. Changed the name since it fits better with black. I have PETG for printing this. Time to print!

Trimmed it down a lot. Simplified and lowered its weight. Instead of standoffs you could use toothpicks?

Will it fly? Will the rubber bands decrease or increase vibrations? Will they help to absorb any shock to the motors and or frame when it crashes? What effect, if any, will this have on the camera and video feed quality? Or will the whole thing implode from the tension?

Peace and happy and safe printing and flying!

description.text:
If you have a set of Probe Master 8000 series probes as well as a Fluke DMM, you would have noticed that the comfy, nubby handles of the Probe Master probes are way too wide and round to fit into a standard Fluke case.

These Probe Master probes are also extremely sharp and pointy – not exactly a good thing to have lying loose in your toolbox, and not something you want to get dinged either. This is why I came up with this thing.

You insert this little adapter into the probe holders of your Fluke. A form-fitting hole allows you to snugly press-fit the Probe Master probes into the adapter, which makes for a much safer and tidier package for your DMM when it's ready to go back into the toolbox.

DMM models tested:

  • Fluke 87V
  • Fluke 114

description.text:
Fractal-based volumetric object that resembles a bird. Sort of.
RAW data 400x400x400 8-bit zipped
PNG codec AVI 400x400x400
PLY isosurface mesh 1M polygons
STL isosurface mesh (reduced) 450K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects. Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here: 40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371 Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here: http://www.engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

comments.author: KowalskiFlausn

comments.text:
Hello KowalskiFlausn,
I think your totally right!
It was something I was thinking about, if you send water true this pipes it takes the frequency footprint of the ABS in the waters memory again and you don’t want that.. besides the fact ABS pollutes the water anyway, what you point out.. I didn’t know that.
What material should people use for this?
comments.author: KowalskiFlausn

comments.text:
Well besides the fact I only know of people who believe in the memory function of water (I don't) and not really about that memory function itself, it also depends in which country you're in. In Europe the finished object is declared food safe after some testing. In USA afaik the filament has to be food safe.
However, as I told you, I don't really know about what would be a bad memory (excuse me, if it's not the correct term). But maybe this link will help: https://all3dp.com/1/food-safe-3d-printing-abs-pla-food-safe-filament/
In short: PLA and PETG are usually considered food safe. I would recommend uncolored ones.

description.text:
THREE JAW GRIPPER
This gripper utilizes toggle arms to open and close the gripper fingers by pulling the center cam pin. The fingers open and close concentrically with about a 1/2" of travel per finger. No fasteners or glue are required for assembly, the pivot pins trap the parts in place. No supports are required if you print the parts as oriented. The cam pin does have some overhangs but caused no problems.

title: Starfield LED Ceiling-/Wall-Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a very compact and flat (WxLxH 20x20x1,7cm) ceilling-/wall lamp. The lamp accommodates 41 LEDs that shine through small holes to create the look-and-feel of a starry sky. Really nice once you have it hanging on the ceiling!

It heavily depends on your requirements how much work it will cost until you can enjoy the simulated starry sky. Or the requirements of your companion. :-)

I added some pictures and videos that show what pain I underwent to get a lamp with a really nice finish. I have a couple of learnings and suggestions if you plan to create a lamp like this (or this lamp). But first how I did it.

1 - Printed the case and cover with PLA in about 12 hours.

2 - Light sanding with 320 grid to prepare for filling the gaps with spray filler (german "Spritzspachtel").

3 - Three times spraying with filler, drying, and sanding.
Then I realized that the cover was too thin (1st version had a thickness of only 1.2mm) because the layers of filler had contracted the cover. It was no longer flat but bent. I tried to correct my mistake with a heat gun. The idea was to lay the cover on a flat surface, put something heavy on it, and then gently heat it up to the glass temperature so it will flatten and cool down. That seemed to work but in the end I messed up not only the cover but also the bottom. OMG!
I had to reprint both parts but thickened the cover to 2+mms. Additionally, I did not use spray filler this time but 2K plastic filler. One layer was enough and if you really, really want to :-), you can watch this time lapse video of the sanding, drilling, and soldering process.

5 - Drilling: The filler prolapsed into a couple of holes so I had to use a 2.5mm (wood) drill to reopen them.

4 - Painting: I wanted a deep gray (anthracite) which was not available in my local hardware store. So I chose zinc dust spray instead which is in fact intended to be sprayed on metallic surfaces, not on plastic. Well, no risk, no fun! And to be consistent, I also resigned from using a base coating. But the painting went well and I finished three layers of the zinc dust spray with two layers of clear coat.

5 - LED assembly. The supply voltage would be 12V using a 230V->12V converter. Now, how to wire 41 SMD LEDs with a forward voltage of 3V and a power consumption of 20mA each? Since the forward voltage is 3V we can put three LEDs in series with an intermediary resistor with 150Ω (12V-(3x3V)=3V/0,02A=150Ω). The remaining two LEDs consume only 6V so the remaining 6V have to be "used up" by a resistor. With U=RxI => R=U/I=6V/0,02A=300Ω. Since the current is low, there should not be any issues with excess heat regarding the resistor, but let's compute the power consumption to be sure. P=UxI=6V*0,02A=0,12W. Thus, we should be fine with a 320Ω, 0,25W resistor.
The assembly itself is not difficult but requires a calm hand and patience. I first glued the LEDs to the cover and then soldered the wires to the LEDs.
Please note that I recycled the LEDs from an old outdoor LED strip where the 150Ω resistor was already on the strip in series with every 3-LED-chunk.

6 - The cover is attached to the case with round 8x1mm magnets. There is a security screw in the center of the lamp but it turned out that the magnets hold sufficiently. I only used the slots on the outer rim of the cover/case though there are pillars in the middle that can accommodate an additional four magnets. I used super glue to glue the magnets to the slots.

Lessons learned

  • No need for more than eight magnets. The design could be adapted accordingly.
  • No need for the security screw. The design could be adapted accordingly.
  • If using 2K plastic filler: Consider printing a cover without holes but just marks on the inside. Print, fill, sand, and then drill the holes. Should speed up the print (a little).
  • Color temperature of LEDs: You should definitely check the color temperature of your LEDs prior to soldering them! I thought(!) that mine were "warm white" but when all the soldering was done and the lamp hung on the ceiling I realized that the color was more of a blueish white. Blueisch white did not match all the other warm white lamps in the room so I had to take down the cover, rip apart all the soldering and glue and solder everything anew with some recycled LEDs from an old outdoor LED strip. Not funny!

Suggestions

  • All that filling and sanding is a tedious and time consuming work. If you happen to have a 3D printer that produces nice prints or if you are happy with how 3D printed pieces look like in general, you can save a lot of work by omitting the filling and sanding part.
  • The LED assembly is also a tedious work. Could be sped up tremendously by using a fairy strip light (copper wire lights) like this amzon.com or this amazon.de. Nonetheless, you would have to plug all the copper wire in the case (enough space?) and the stars will most likely be more dim than "regular" ones.

comments.text: Nicely done. I wonder how it would look using colored LEDs. I got some of these self changing RBG LEDs recently (https://www.ebay.com/itm/100x-3mm-Slow-RGB-Flash-Rainbow-MultiColor-LED-Light-Lamp-Bulb-New-Free-Shipping/171628818405?epid=519640209&hash=item27f5dfefe5:g:kl0AAOSwAL9UgJN0). Maybe you could create rims on the top to hold them. I would probably use a constant current circuit to drive the LEDs rather than relying on the voltage drop of each LED in series. Plenty of food for thought :-)
comments.author: KiwiGrinder

comments.text:
Hi John,
many thanks! I think that colored LEDs would add a nice disco feeling. :-) A really awesome solution could also be to use RGB LEDs (WS2812b or alike) and control them for virtually unlimited lighting effects with, e.g., an Arduino. But that would have been an overkill for my use case.
I considered some sort of rim, but decided to glue them in the end which worked quite well.
Regarding constant current vs. voltage: That is very interesting and while I stumbled during my search for an appropriate converter over constant current ones, I never really gave it a second thought. Which changed now, thanks to you, and I am, at least, at little wiser than before. I understand, that variations in forward voltages between the LEDs can lead to varying current consumption and, thus, impact their brightness and/or life-span (thermal wear out). The first LEDs I used all came from the same batch, so I would have hoped that their current consumption is more or less equal. However, since the color temperature was blueish white and a no got, I disassembled everything and recycled some really warm white LEDs from an old outdoor LED stripe. The converter that came with this stripe is a constant voltage one and the LEDs were set in series of three with an intermediary 151Ω resistor. I copied that exact same setup to my lamp and hope that it will last the next couple of years.
Nonetheless, a constant current setup to power LEDs (esp. white ones and high-power LEDs) seems to be recommended. Though I think, that the circuitry will be more complex than for the constant voltage setup.
Best wishes
Axel
comments.author: KiwiGrinder

title: Lead_Screw_Bracket (Self-Adjusting)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I feel that a fixed Lead Screw Bracket, as in the D-Box, invites trouble.
It presupposes that the bed supports will be horizontal. They are never. Close, but not quite.
The lead screw nuts can take a little bit of an angle against the lead screws but not much, they are not meant to. And before you know it the torque results in more friction then the stepper wants to handle.

These self adjusting lead screw brackets can take that angle without bothering the lead screw nuts with it. There are 2 versions, 1 full plastic, called simple, and 1 with ball bearings.

Because, after I made the full plastic one, I began to wonder what the pressure between the 2 parts would do to the friction between them over time, plastic being plastic.
It worked completely according to plan and I think that after mounting very little, if any, adjusting is needed until such time that there is a change somewhere that would influence the position of the bed supports. And I am not sure whether at that time the parts would have set more fixed on each other, thus preventing self adjusting, or not.
I just don't know enough about plastics to be certain one way or the other.

So I made also a version where the pressure is left to a ball bearing.
It is a little more complicated then the straightforward all-plastic version so I thought to offer you both versions and you can decide for yourself which one to pick.

I printed everything without support: TLC remains necessary with support too.

For the first version I used 4 M5x16 bolts + washers + hammer heads and 4 M3x18-20 bolts + washers + lock nuts. Not more then 20mm because of the room needed for rotating.
The distance between bed support and lead screw remains the same as before, so you can exchange the parts without moving the stepper motor mounts.

For the version with a ball bearing I used for the ball bearing assembly:

  • 1 Ball Bearing MR105ZZ (ø5xø10x4) (the same as one uses for the wheels)
  • 2 brass shims ø8xø5x1
  • 1 M5x16 bolt + washer + lock nut.
    Check the images: the shims are not symmetrical with respect to part 1, for the purpose of easier printing.
    And again 4 M3x18-20 bolts + washers + lock nuts for the lead screw nut. As you can see there is just room for longer bolts.

I am sure you will need some TLC to fit the ball bearing into part 1, because I made the hole ø10mm, same as the ball bearing, although I believe that there is always pressure downward and extra room would be taken care of without causing problems.
But perhaps I'm wrong, so now you can make it fit nicely.

For part 2 I used 2 M5x16 bolts + washers + hammer heads
Check that the bolt-head from the ball bearing assy goes easily into the lower hole of part 2.
For part 3 I used, apart from the ball bearing stuff, 2 M5x10 bolts + washers + hammer heads.
In this version there is 1mm more distance from the bed support to the lead screw compared to the original, so you want to check the stepper motor mount places. It was necessary to have some room for the ball bearing bolt and I did want to use the usual variety of bolts, not the ones with flat heads.

In both versions you need to check after mounting whether there is enough play for part 1 to move easily between part 2 and the rail.

I would appreciate your comments, especially whether you agree that adjusting is wanted and on the plastic-setting point. ;-)

Edit (10/01/18): Things looked so bad for a moment that I thought this thing was seriously flawed, because all of a sudden the lead screw went very much askew when I lowered the bed completely, but now I had time to look at it again, I think that shit happened because I let this thing crash into the flexible motor coupling.
I don't think it is a good idea to make the thing thinner, to make room for the coupling, so I leave it as it is, with the warning that you should check your lower z-endstop to prevent it from happening to you.
Looking at the thing more closely I saw that it just worked better than I thought in the sense that you could see the angle change just a little bit when the bed travels from high up to completely down, as it should, of course, because the angle between the bed supports and the lead screw changes a bit when moving up and down, but I hadn't thought of it. ;-) The more reason to feel that this thing is necessary.

And again, this movement diminishes the chance that the complete plastic thing gets fixated, when one uses that.
At the same time I think that I prefer the ball bearings even more, because I feel that those can follow these small changes easier.

comments.text: A step in the right direction but it only works in one plane.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
True, but for the other directions you can, and have to, find and adjust the right position for yourself, by placing the motor mounts and the bracket correctly.
This correction you cannot make manually, that's why I made it.
I made an adjustable bracket for a third lead screw, when I used that, for a similar reason: there I couldn't adjust that 3rd lead screw in the Y-direction. Although I don't use it any more you can still find it here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2094263/#files.
I considered combining the 2, but then the X-direction would feel left out, and who would want that?
Furthermore, the aberration for which you have to correct here is very limited. I made room for a 4 degree angle both ways and that's more then you would ever need, I hope for you. The 3rd lead screw needed also a very limited correction.
How far would you want to reach corrections in the X- an Y-directions?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: There's always Oldham style couplings too. I'v e seen one or two printed versions but the needed tolerances may be too strict.
comments.author: printingSome

comments.text:
Didn't know those, could work perhaps, but are not necessary. As I said, the other 2 directions can be adjusted for in mounting and you would have to do that anyway and then you can do that with enough accuracy when you're at it. Though I am not a big fan of doing it.
And the tolerances here are not strict at all. ;-)

description.text:
Esta es mi propia versión del filtro de filamento. Está hecha como dos piezas iguales que se montan simetricamente unidas con pasadores (lo más sencillo es usar un clip normal cortado al efecto) uno de los lados se puede dejar permanente como bisagra, mientras que el otro debe poder quitarse y se usa como cierre. En fin la forma de montarlo es bastante evidente y seguro que se puede hacer de mil formas diferentes.
La forma de uso es la misma que el resto de filtros, en su interior se pone esponja o algo equivalente (yo he utilizado un trozo de mopa atrapa polvo). Se le vierten unas gotas de aceite mineral y se pasa el filamento por el medio para que se limpie y se lubrique.
La ventaja de hacerlo en dos partes que se abren es que es más fácil de pasar el filamento ya que no hay que ir haciendo puntería entre los agujerillos de entrada y salida. También es más sencillo poner aceite de forma uniforme.
En fin ahí lo dejo para uso público.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

No importa

Notes:

Hay qwue ponerle soportes para los pasantes de fijación y para la cara superior.
No se necesita relleno porque las paredes son finas y si se utilizan tres perímetros y tres capas superiores e inferiores con un nozzle de 0,4 ya da el grosor requerido.
La resolución de 0.3 es más que suficiente para la pieza.

title: T joint for 21.5mm or 3/4 waste pipe (UK). Not for plumbing

description.text: The is a T joint designed in Fusion 360. It is a good fit for 3/4 or 21.5mm waste pipe available in the UK. The 21.5 waste pipe from B&Q to be precise. I believe that there are other sizes which might be sold under the title 3/4, so being specific that available from B&Q and sold as 21.5. In Homebase it is 22mm and I have no idea if the joint will fit but of course it can be scaled if you are prepared for a bit of trial and error. It will join the pipe so it can be used for framing for photography backgrounds or other structures such as 3D printer enclosures. This was printed in .4 rough draft and I am unsure if the quality of the print and tolerances that your printer may print to will effect the diameter. You are of course free to scale the item if you feel that it will be a more optimal fit at a different size. You may also scale it to use in a different application. I initially printed these upright (Doh!`) if that is the correct way to describe it but I suggest that it would be better printed flat with the cylinders all against the print surface. As you can see I had another go flat. Naturally the result was much better. The fit is much better. In Cura, if a brim is used not a raft, some of the brim will be difficult to remove, so leave that on. This makes for a tighter fit. It is a good tight push fit which will hold the tubes tightly. I have printed on glass therefore if you use another surface the fit might vary. Check what your slicer says about time and materials consumed but I believe that the solid shape may print more economically than if there was a void. If you print this please add a photo. It will be interesting to see how other people have printed this and what wacky colours you have used.

comments.text: Seems it is a Lulzbot Cura 2.6.52 (Ultimaker Cura V2 based) problem because it opens fine with the Lulzbot's legacy 21.08 version of Cura (Ultimaker Cura V1 based). I then opened the problem STL files in Meshlab and there where some errors which Meshlab was able to correct. I was then able to save the repaired STL and open them up in Lulzbot's Cura 2.6.53 just fine. Seems Lulzbot's 2,6,52 version of Cura doesn't handle STL's that any contain errors. I had opened an bug with the luzbot cura developers  in the beta phase of 2.6.x a few months ago and they said they would not fix their STL parsing code, but rather I should fix the STL and they closed the ticket. So for those using Lulzbot's Cura 2.6.x, you have been warned.

description.text:
Este proyecto consiste en desarrollar un camión con piezas impresas en 3D.
Para la base aproveché una que tenía de un kit antiguo y diseñé las demás piezas con la idea de que encajaran y se adaptaran.
El frontal lleva ensamblada la matriz led 8x8, la parte de los "ojos" alberga el sensor de ultrasonidos para medir la distancia y en el techo va insertado el "buzzer". Las piezas se encajan entre ellas mediante ranuras y salientes.
En la parte de atrás lleva dos rampas unidas a sendos servos que las suben y las bajan de forma independiente.
En la parte de abajo de la base están encajados los motores de rotación continua y el sensor infrarrojos para seguir líneas.

description.text:
This is a project based on:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:847674

Where I made a small change in the joystick nut spacer.

New joystick nut spacer: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bJNoivAjtUi

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Support is necessary only for joystick_knob_top.stl

Part List

10 - push button switch R13-507
04 - micro switch
01 - chinese controller like a PS2 controller or a zero delay board

For zero delay board I think will be necessary remove the connectors because of height. In addition it will be necessary wires, soldering iron, Dremel and hot glue.

Electronics

As the controller board has two joystick (L&R) and it won't necessary, after remove this the port will float and will be impossible play because the analog left and digital (up,down,L,R) work together. The best fix is make a voltage divider with two resistor of same value (~2k ohms) as the picture below. You can use only one voltage divider for the four ports.

Drill and cut

Use the Dremel to drill and cut the VHS cover as picture.

Wire solder

With a little patience solder the wires, find the best place for the board and glue the jpystick with hot glue.

A fractal-based volumetric object. It is hollow in the top, and so it could be used as a bowl or vase. As with most fractals though, it has some thin interconnecting pieces, so if you want to make use of it you may want to either add some support or use the trimmed version (bottom portion removed, flat base).
RAW data 400x400x400 8-bit zipped
PNG codec AVI 400x400x400
PLY isosurface mesh 1.5M polygons
STL isosurface mesh (reduced) 990K polygons 
STL isosurface mesh (reduced, trimmed) 800K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects. Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here: 40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371 Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here: http://www.engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

title: 3D printer laser bracket, vent and eye protection tube

description.text:
I read a great instructable by [Jakes Workshop] to turn a 3d printer into a laser engraver, and so I created a bracket for my 2.5 watt laser and Tronxy X3 that i bought from gearbest. I've read about laser safety and at least understand the attributes of the laser class system, so the intention was to take a class 4 laser and incorporate it into a class 1 laser system, but the machine as it works is a little short of that goal. What it does do with the adjustable vent and eye protection tube is reduces the need for laser eye protection (LEP) and reduces the smoke and smell. If the work surface is flat then vent tube can be placed almost on the surface of the work making any spectral reflections trapped, however this could be used incorrectly and it would not be eye safe. Always do your own research, don't trust me! Because even with the tube on i found that in some instances the laser will turn on when i did not want it to, such as when i switch the 3D printer on it flashes the laser a few times until i get my PC connected in repetier software. so how i use it is i keep the LEP on until the work is in place an i'm sure the laser will not go over the edge. The laser I used has an adjustable lens on it, so I set the focal distance to about 86mm, out form the stop about 1 turn, if your lens is adjusted differently then the tube maybe too long or too short.

the process i used to create laser engraving files is following the jakes workshop instructions, and then simply load the file in the repetier software and click print, it runs the Gcode all from the PC. the laser is controlled with a TTL control board that is plugged directly into the 12v second fan plug on the melzi board. the fan on the vent tube is connected to the 12v power supply.

The example item in my photos is transparent PLA, so it glows like a light show when the laser is on, the plastic diffuses the laser light so that it is not coherent, and so eye safe. the 40mm fan has fiberglass filter material stuffed up stream of it so that it has some filtering, but i also run it next to an externally vented hood. the 4mm holes can be tapped after printing with 10/32 threads, but something smaller would be OK too. I designed a hose adapter, but could not find a good hose for it.

author: 0lympy

description.text:
Sherline Mills and Lathes come with a whole bunch of tools, and I love 'em! Keeping them in an orderly manner has always been a challenge, so I created these organizer trays (and more in the pipeline) so that 1) the tools can be kept so that all loose items that belong together can be kept together and not lost in a pile of crap, 2) So that the items can be stacked (more or less) neatly in a tool box and take up less space than having them in zip-lock bags, 3) So that the items can be neatly found when I need 'em (geez - it could take quite a while to find the right screw if it's in a pile of screws), 4) If you're reading this far, it's pretty good! So give yourself a pat on the back!, 5) Cos it's fun making things!

1) Knurling Tool Tray
This tray includes 4 insets for storing spare knurls (2 pairs) and slots for the screws which are not in use (the knurling tool uses long or short screws depending on the diameter of the part to be knurled). It's assumed that the T-nuts are going to be always kept on the knurling tool.

2) Step Down Blocks Tray
This tray has slots at the bottom to keep all the various lengths of screws as pairs and are easy to find when needed. The step down blocks are placed on top of the screws for storage. The divider "posts" are relatively fragile, and are really not that functional, so it shouldn't matter if they broke off.

3) Steady Rests Tray
This tray hols BOTH the Steady Rest and the Follower Rest. The brass bars of the Follower rest have to be removed from the rest body and stored in the slot provided. The bars of the steady rest can be left in place, but pushed to the innermost posiiton. This was done in order to minimize the box size required. The follower rests hold down tab is also housed in a slot at the top of the box.

4) Radius Cutter Tray
This tray holds the 3 main items of the radius cutter kit snugly and keeps the cutter supports (with their very sharp centers) away from each other.

4) Machine Vice Tray
This tray holds the machine vice and it has higher walls so that the hold down clamps and T nuts can also be stored in the same tray. There are slots in the side wall so that it is easy to grasp the vice to remove it from the box.
This part was made using Fusion 360. Let me know if you need the source file, or would like to collaborate on this and other Sherline tool trays (and other Sherline gidgets) designs!

author: amin95

title: Chi-Ren Chen's Intrude2 puzzle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A difficult 6 x 6 x 3 puzzle consisting of a ring and four identical blocks.
Fit the blocks into the ring and slide them around to make the final shape. No rotations required. Original design at http://puzzlewillbeplayed.com/663Ring/Intrude2/ I have included the .xmpuzzle file which can be loaded into Burr Tools if you need help with the solution.

Print one of the rings and four copies of the block.
The STL files have been designed based on 10 mm unit cubes with a 1 mm bevel and a 0.1 mm offset to allow easy movement of the pieces.
I printed mine with 0.2 mm layer height, two perimeters and 20% infill, four bottom layers and six top layers should ensure that any irregularities in the top surface get smoothed out.

comments.author: gummybear223

comments.text: Sorry to hear that. I couldn’t see a picture of your print so I can’t be sure but my suspicion is that your printer may be over-extruding. I say this because if the flow rate is even only 1% over, the parts will not fit together. I have spent hours tuning my printer to make sure that the parts measure exactly the right dimensions and my current extrusion multiplier value is 90% of the calculated E steps/mm value.

Download the .xmpuzzle file. Run Burr Tools. File/Load and select the .xmpuzzle file.
Click the Solver tab. Check the Disassemble box. Click Start.
Find the slider just under the Move label. Scroll right and left to disassemble the puzzle.
Can also use right and left arrow on the keyboard for fine control.
Click and drag on the puzzle to rotate it. Zoom in for a clearer view.

title: Tracking Tag - Adafruit Feather M0 / Wing GPS

description.text:
Using the Adafruit Feather case design and Fusion 360 an enclosure was created to hold a tracking tag using a Feather M0 w/ WiFi and a Wing GPS boards from Anafruit, along with a 3.7V 1200 mAh LiPo battery. The width of the case was reduced to match the 1200 mAh battery where a the slide switch is located in the main housing given the battery compartment is too shallow to enclose the switch. The main housing height was increased to accommodate stacking the GPS wing on top of the Feather M0, where the lowest height headers offered by Adafruit were employed.

The Adafruit Fusion 360 design includes use of user parameters to enable changing key dimensions such as width and height. That said when reducing the box's width the sketch for the slide switch was improperly linked. The result was the retention bosses were outside of the main box, thus these features were modified.

While not fixed in the posted STLs, the opening for the USB is too small for most cables such that the USB data pins will not make contact. I struggled with Fusion 360 attempting to fix this feature but gave up and got out the knife opening up the USB feature after printing the main body.

Another issue with the Adafruit design is that lateral tolerance for the attachment features for the top and battery box is too large. Technically the snap tolerance is settable in the user parameters, but the fact the top and battery bottom slide back and forth a huge amount making the final assembly appear to be poorly designed junk. This issue was not fixed in the attached STLs, though I might go back and do battle again with Fusion 360 in an attempt to repair the overall snap feature tolerances.

Overall I found the Fusion 360 design from Adafruit welcome rather than starting from scratch, but in the end it was more frustration that it was worth.

For 80mm

This is a magnetic dart. A normal whiteboard with any drawing on it can be used as a target.
You need to print the tail, cut it to be square, fold it and insert it in the dart body. (You can create any tail you like).
Further you need a round magnet 10 mm and 5 mm height. You can buy those in the internet (i.e. supermagnets.ch).
Also cut a 2 cm disc with a 1 cm hole to glue around the magnet. This is for shock absorption I used a 3 mm isolation foam.

For the tail-fin: there is a .pdf file as an example.
Print out this file borderless preferably on A4 format (American format should not make much of a difference)

After printing cut the paper to become square.
Fold the ends along the horizontal line up (Valley fold)
Fold back turn 90 degrees and fold the ends according the vertical line up (Valley fold)

Turn the paper over and fold the paper according to the dotted diagonal lines (mountain fold)
Repeat for the other diagonal

Than form the fin as shown in the picture (hold the end together with 4 fingers.
Make sure that the tip is "sharp".

Insert the tip in the body. The cuts in the body are inside tapered to accommodate the 90 degree angle of the tip.
When you use 80g paper, glue is not needed (at least for the result on my printer, Da Vinci Mini W)

I will add some pictures to explain this

description.text:
I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, this is part of my bin set. I do own all but the Scum ships, so there will be bins for them at some point.

My design goals:

  • Attractive Presentation

So, here is my design for the TIE Bomber.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

author: 3D_Pressure

description.text:
After playing with the HTC Vive a while you'll find when you take off the HMD you'll have a very sweaty face. Others have found that having a fan blow on your forehead helps keep you cool, but I wanted a way that didn't cost $30+ to achieve the same thing.

There are generic laptop coolors available on Amazon.com, Walmart, eBay, etc for <$5 so I created these mounts to allow you to mount an inexpensive USB fan to your headset. (I found mine searching for USB Mini Octopus Laptop Fan)

Pop the four laptop supports out of the fan, then plug the USB plug into the top of the HMD. Put the replacement mounts into the fan (the pegs should snap into place). They spin, so they're adjustable to the HMD angles. Use the printed pegs or two small metal screws to act as hinge pins. Use two pieces of double stick tape to attach the mounts to the top of the HMD and you're done. If you want the ability to easily turn the fan on and off you can add a USB switch to the mix.

Pics of the basic fan, USB switch, and assembled fan. I'll post one of the fan on the HMD later.

11/28/2017 - revised the design to remove the pins/screws. This should be easier to assemble and use. I also widened the base piece to accommodate the new mounting style.

12/11/2017 - added photos and a video of the fan installed. Mine currently doesn't have an on/off switch so it is always running when the headset usb is plugged in. You'll want to use some strong double-sided tape if you're using the small brackets as they are not contoured to fit perfectly flush against the headset. I'm working on a longer, single bar type mount to try to fix some stability issues, but it does work as currently uploaded.
